reviews.review_text: Rating: 7.5/10 Overview: FPS with the ability to go into slow-mo   The Good:  +Game looks good both artisically and technically. Game also makes good use of lighting  + Game has a variety of weapons and grenades. Certain weapons are very creative while others are what you would expect in a FPS  + The game has really solid level design. In addition, the game takes place over a series of different environments and locations. One of my biggest complaints in the first FEAR was that the environments were too similar and felt repetitive so it's nice to see this was fixed in the sequel.   +The shooting mechanics feel good, going into slow-mo and shooting enemies is always fun. The game also introduces sections where you ride a mech to change up the gameplay.  The Average:  The AI feels average compared to the first FEAR. The first game was renowned for its amazing AI and to this day I still think it sets the standard for AI in a FPS game. This game though doesn't seem to have that. The AI is not bad by any means, however compared to the first game it doesn't feel close.  The horror elements are not as a good as the first game. Between finding a balance between action and horror the developers chose action. There are certainly plenty of times the game tries to invoke scares but sometimes it just comes across as flat.   One of the most satisfying weapons in any FPS game was the shotgun from the first game. In this game, the shotgun doesn't even feel close to satisfying.   I found the game to be very easy even on the normal setting, play on hard if you want a challenge.   The Bad:  - The dialogue in this game is terrible. It makes the story feel like a straight to home video release. It becomes difficult to take the story seriously or be afraid of what's around the corner when the characters are saying things that just make you shake your head.    -The game has a certain flow to it but the entire ending gameplay segment feels frustrating and out of place.   -Multiplayer is dead  Conclusion  On the one hand this game does things a lot better than the first, on the other hand it also doesn't seem to improve any of the flaws and in some cases makes it worse. What could have been a really great horror FPS game turns into you standard run of the mill FPS game. For a FPS game it is very solid and should provide you with a 5-6 hours of fun.

Played F.E.A.R. several years ago with a buddy of mine, great game even though my memories are now almost gone..  F.E.A.R. 2 Project Origin is quite a beautiful sequel: it's an 'old school' First Person Shooter, you know about that: get the ammo, medpacks and fight replicas (enemy soldiers) while following Alma's trails (main story).  The most peculiar feature of this game series is time reflex enhancement which lets you slow down time, giving you a tactical advantage over a crowded enemy line. Game is plain simple, advance to next level taking down enemies and that's pretty much about it but you have nice weapons, different type of bad people along the way - not only soldiers but visions and monsters/creepy creatures. The setting is dark and there's plenty of blood, gore; visual effects are very well done too, vivid colors and spark lights contrast the black surroundings.  Gameplay gets entertaining from the beginning to the end because there are many cutscenes, the story is well told and developed: you could say this is a 'complete' FPS which doesn't go down in any aspect - it may not be a masterpiece but I think it's worth playing, especially 'if you already had F.E.A.R.' :)

Oh, and I had to change the difficulty from Hard to Normal at the very end because it was over-the-top difficult. I hate when I have to do that. I'm all for a challenge, that's why I set it to Hard in the first place. But when you go overboard and bump the difficulty of the last levels from Hard to Yeah-You-Aren't-Finishing-The-Game-At-This-Difficulty you ruin an otherwise engaging experience.  Like in the first F.E.A.R. I had fun again but I don't know why. The story wasn't too compelling, the gameplay was predictable (or I'm getting good at seeing arenas when they are shown to me) and the entire premise is just...forced. But it's a fun game.

There were answers and tidbits of information throughout, there was atmosphere, some occasional scares, sci-fi mystery, the action is far better than the first FEAR thanks to things like iron sights and select fire as well as the different grenades/explosives you have at your disposal. The story was, for me, quite engaging. I was very interested in finding out how things progressed, and the end had me looking forward to FEAR 3. Well, you can check my review on that if you like, but here's the several paragraphs of hatred summed up in 2 words: It Sucked.  I find FEAR 2 to be by far the best in the series, FEAR 1 is 2nd best with monotonous but acceptable combat as well as great atmosphere, and FEAR 3 is... well, let's not ruin the moment by bringing that up again. I wholeheartedly suggest getting this game, and while I think it'd be good to play FEAR 1 first, I definitely think this game can be enjoyed without doing things chronologically. Just... make sure you STOP at FEAR 2, unless you don't give a ♥♥♥♥ about story or firearm realism, just wanting to blow stuff up with the occasional little needless spook from Alma or other unexplained monsters. Maybe FEAR 4 won't suck... but if it still focuses on that ridiculous 'brother' nonsense, screw that...

F.E.A.R 2 is a divisive game amongst series fans, and the majority of the hate it gets doesn't make sense.   There's only one real complaint I have with F.E.A.R 2, which is the game just doesn't seem to have the same level of care as the original.   By level of care, I mean: -The FOV needs to be set through a .cfg  -You can't lean -There's a weird delay to sprinting -The hud is terrible -The game feels slimmed down.   They're all minor quips, but they're noticable. If you're willing to give it a chance, F.E.A.R 2 is a worthy successor that I feel surpasses the original in some respects. It's not as good as Extraction Point, but it's a game that's definitely worth a play. It does suffer from Wolfenstein: The New Order syndrome, so know that the game gets much better after the first three chapters.  Play on hard and make sure to get the fixed hud mod through me or google because the standard hud is straight fugly.

What is F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin? -- F.E.A.R. 2 is the successor of F.E.A.R., an immersive psycho-horror FPS with a fantastic bullet time mechanic. -- -- Who would most enjoy F.E.A.R. 2? -- If you loved the first F.E.A.R. game, you'll most likely love this title as well. That being said, if you felt the first game was too visually dated for your tastes, or too mechanically clunky, the game has improved leaps and bounds in that department. The game also favors action packed gun-battles a little bit more heavily than the first. The tension is very slightly lighter than the first game, but it holds enough strengths to more than compensate for this. -- -- Over-all: 80.0% As a whole, F.E.A.R. 2 is a more solid title than the first game, and will appeal to a wider audience. That being said, some of the elements that make F.E.A.R. 2 a better game as a whole, slightly subtract from the immersive experience that was the terrifying glory of the first F.E.A.R. game. -- Mechanics: 4/5 The mechanics are a definiteive improvement here, over the first game. Movement in much more fluid, bullet time is possibly even more smoothly integrated, there's more interaction with the world and terrain, the AI is very well done this time around, and as a whole, the game feels very appropriately smooth and fluid. -- Experience: 4/5 In the five years between the release of F.E.A.R. 1 and F.E.A.R. 2, the developers have come along way in improving the audio and visuals of the game. The game went from passibly average looking (just enough so's to not distract from the experience) to downright gorgeous. The textures are fairly average, but the artistic embellishments in conjunction with the fantastic visual effects definitely help this game shine. The audio has also taken a massive leap, helping tie the experience together. With all that being said, the psycho-horror elements of the game have been toned down just a touch, and that in combination with a few crowd pleaser moments, and the addition of collectible bits of intel, actually subtract from the experience slightly, in my opinion. The game is still fantastically immersive, and will draw you in, unlike many other titles to date, but in comparison with the first title, I feel F.E.A.R. 2 sacrifices a chunk of it's biggest strength -- the raw gripping psycho-horror elements, for a few fun, but unnecessary scripted gun battles. Balance: 4/5  -- Longevity: 4/5 The game is slightly shorter than the first game in the series, containing only 14 missions of roughly 30-45 minute length each. That being said, it doesn't rely solely on the immersive experience, unlike the first game, and provides a number little bits of intel for the player to run around and find, if that's your thing. There may be room for a second playthrough with F.E.A.R. 2, between looking to find the rest of the missed bits of intel, playing through on a higher difficulty, or simply just to enjoy the beauty and fluidity of the game for second time.

F.E.A.R. 2 takes place concurrently (only for a short time) and during the aftermath of the first F.E.A.R. You play a SFOD soldier named Becket whose team is grabbed by Armacham, juiced full of experimental drugs, and then sent on a mission to stop Alma while chasing down leads on the how and the why of it all. You get the gist of the story in radio communications and in-game cutscenes but all the details are in logs scattered throughout the levels, similar to the first game but there's a lot of more of them this time.  F.E.A.R. had amazing graphics at the time and Project Origin doesn't disappoint. The effects are similar to the first game with lots of sparks and dust when the bullets fly. The best looking effects come when you're having hallucinations. Colors fade, return, your view goes blurry and sharp, lights flash on and off. It's impossible to describe effectively.  A big complaint about the first game was the lack of variety in environments. It was a lot of offices and industrial areas. Personally it didn't bother me much, but Monolith took it to heart. Of course there's more offices and industrial parks but there's also a school, a medical facility, research labs, and the destroyed streets of Auburn. You never feel like you're walking the same corridors over and over and no one environment really overstays its welcome.  F.E.A.R. 2 also has the same fantastic gunplay that the first game had. Enemies are quasi-intelligent in dropping for cover and flanking your positions. That said, on normal difficulty, the game never gets too hard. I don't think I died a single time. Between the abundance of armor and health packs, the whole game is just a little easy. The only nuance that threw me at the beginning is that when you hit the slo-mo button on and off, there's a little bit of a spin-up and spin-down. It was basically an on-off switch in the first game so having a second of delay really threw me off at the beginning.  My favorite part of this game were the areas where you get to stomp around in the elite power armor. It isn't just for the amazing amounts of firepower the elite power armor brings, or the carnage of the fights you get into with it, but the effects while you're in it. As it takes more damage, alarms scream, the screen gets distorted, and warnings flash manically. It's a hell of a lot of fun and really makes me clamor for Monolith to make good on the easter eggs it's put in recent games and make a sequel to SHOGO: Mobile Armor Division, a mech game they made a decade ago.  There's no easier way to put it: F.E.A.R. 2 is an awesome first-person shooter. I played through it all in a single day, which is a task I don't think I've ever done. It's basically amazing.

F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin:  Intro:  Alma is back in the second game of F.E.A.R. named F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin. If you enjoyed the first game this will be worth your money.  Do not expect this game to be a better version of the original game – there is no such a thing!  This game got some improvements compared to the first F.E.A.R. game, but a lot of downsides as well.  Graphic, controls, performance, & sound:  Graphic: The overall graphics got enchanted to look shinier and more modern - I especially like the blood which looks a lot more like liquid compared to the first one, plus an added effect, bodies also drop organs sometimes when they explode - however I miss the random body part (like a arm or a leg) that could fly off into the distance from the first F.E.A.R. game. Generally effects like: explosions, bullet impacts on surface or ground and shotgun bursts, looks absolutely terrible in my option, its way to white/yellow and without any detail, looks like something done in a hurry and is very a shame!  Controls: All controls can be customized and is a great way to use your own key liking. Also a new thing in F.E.A.R.2 is the sprint mechanic, however one thing I didn’t like is that you cannot toggle it on and off; if you toggle on your sprint it’ll last as long as the sprint meter is up, that can lead to awkward situations where you just need to stop up in a hurry even a half second faster count, if trying to avoid incoming attacks or taking cover.  Performance: I haven’t had any performance issues at all running the game maxed out, always on a steady/capped 60 fps even on a low-end CPU and a small amount of ram.  Sound: The sound effects work very well to create the dark and creepy atmosphere this game is going for. A common thing in the F.E.A.R. series is a high pitch noise whenever a scare is coming up, if I like it or not is the question, one could say it is hard to be taken off guard with such a mechanic.   Horror:  Scares in the world of F.E.A.R. is a great thing, and I like that Alma appeared this much in the second game, however, the same kind of scares appeared way too often which only made it annoying and predictable. Asides from the point on scares (jump scares) this game has a surprisingly large focus on the small and creepy details of the horror genre, if one is to explore around like I did on my second walkthrough. I found a lot of things that I missed blindly first time, simply because I didn’t notice it, and that’s something I admire of a horror game. “You may not even realize they could be watching yah, aye?”  Artificial Intelligence:  The AI replica soldiers got a lot dumber compared to the first F.E.A.R. (or its expansions), their behavior is too monotonous, which makes killing them a little tedious and like a routine you go through.  Their awareness is also not working like it should: Moving from floor 1 and up in the right side by the stairs, the AI’s standing on the left side of floor 2 spotted me, because I had a flashlight on (they yelling: we got a flashlight over here) – even though a wall was blocking their sight on floor 2. Uh makes sense? I think not!  Overall:  Even though this review may sound rather critical and demeaning, I do not mean any of it in a negative manner, and the game does have its good moments. This review is simply based on my own perspective, from my experience and thoughts about the game and I’ll certainly recommend it if you enjoyed the original F.E.A.R. game or its expansions and couldn’t get enough. The playtime value is about 12 hours.   F.E.A.R. 2: Reborn:  A very small DLC to the original F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin.  I am not very impressed by the DLC due to the leak of new content.  One thing the DLC did provide was some missing information for the 3rd F.E.A.R. game, but that alone isn’t worth getting the DLC for, in my option.  Very low playtime value, I completed the DLC in less than an hour.

Pretty damn good game. Short but sweet. While not entirely bug-free, it's a lot more polished than its prequel. The game also seems to be a bit more clever with its scares, making the scary bits a lot more enjoyable.  The level design is on par with the original FEAR, though a little more varied. Paths to objectives are unrealistically complex, but fun nonetheless.  Combat is different. The AI seems to be less intelligent but can handle more damage and is more accurate when shooting. Some enemies towards the end can take a bit too much damage to my liking, but not to the point where it gets frustrating. There is no more peeking from cover, meaning you can't fight the same as you did in the original FEAR. On the other hand, it's much easier to flank enemies than it is in the original. While I prefer the original combat and enemies, I don't dislike the ones in FEAR 2. With the exception of fighting monsters, that is.  The game's biggest fault, is that they wanted to include more enemy variety and ended up with some complete BS monsters. There's the fast-but-weak creepy-crawly monsters that are just an annoyance because they do so little damage but are hard to hit and the puppeteer monster that takes a ♥♥♥♥♥on of damage, keeps running away and has the most annoying attack in the world. The latter monster is challenging, sure, but also a real chore.  The story is pretty fun, until you start to think about it and you discover some things that don't quite make sense (or aren't adequately explained, at least). The original game was the same, though.  Both FEAR and FEAR 2 are must-plays.

I'm not going to waste time trying to make this post presentable, so here's a stream of consciousness (all comparisons are held against F.E.A.R. 1):  Dirty dirty console port, cell shaded graphics do not fit the theme, aiming feels inaccurate, the AI is stupider, there are no graphics settings other than to change the resolution, spawn points are blatantly obvious and depressingly-purposefully annoying, the game speed is slow enough where you don't even need slo mo (fear1 is so fast you actually need it), overall it's too easy to really get into combat yet I get instakilled frequently by things I can't see (enemies spawn right behind you). FEAR1 had sprawling levels where squads could strategically engage you (or be engaged by you)- FEAR2 is all cheap spawn points in linear, uninspired level design. Ammo is dropped every two inches, it can't differentiate between left CTRL and right CTRL (fear1 could), it bugs out if you press too many keys at once (it often gets stuck strafing right, it often doesn't register keypresses, etc). Moreover the story is filled with cheap thrills and the plot is insanely stupid- they've never heard of 'less is more'. And the way alma is rendered is also less scary.  FEAR1's plot wasn't a masterpiece by any stretch; it had some really good and unique ideas in the meat of the story, but the frame-plot / getting to the meat of the story was pretty blatantly stupid. However it was at least *paced*; seems to me like they just wanted to play with some neat horror ideas and didn't really care too much about the rest of the plot- any excuse to get the player alone in some creepy environments would do. The game is about exploring ideas, and it is about exploring Alma's backstory; clearly not a lot of effort was put into leading up to that. Knowing that the plot was largely bad, they interspersed truly intriguing elements along the way and approached the more interesting ideas *slowly*.  FEAR2's approach to storytelling is to have some guy call you up and explain just about everything to you. There's no suspense or pacing. It's just... all bad.  ------------------------------------- F.E.A.R. 2 Reborn DLC ------------------------------------- This one really builds you up just to let you down- in the beginning, things look AWESOME. Several huge issues with FEAR2 are corrected! Points in Reborn's favor:  - You control a replica soldier - without slow motion abilities - with health given in numbers rather than a bar (both are good but if you have to pick one, go with numbers). - working in tandem with a squad of ally replica soldiers - with a clear, concise, simple objective that isn't stupid - You pursue enemies across sandbox like maps- no jack in the box spawn points! Enemies are actually walking around! - You are actually made vulnerable at one point; you have nothing but your firsts and you must figure out how to kill a patrol of 6-7 enemies often walking in pairs WITHOUT SLOWMO! A challenge! Well not really, there's an obviously scripted opening in which a pair split up and one of them faces his back to you long enough for you to easily kill him, grab his gun and shoot his partner. But hey, better than any given situation in all of FEAR2  Then fettel gives you hallucinations in which you shoot at ghosts in self defense. When you get back to reality, you see that you have killed your squad. That is a praiseworthy mechanic and story element- or it would be if it were in a different game exploring the effects of PTSD. Here it is simply a convenient way for the game to start being complete ♥♥♥♥.  Now, - you have slow mo - you have no squad, and everything that moves is your enemy - enemies spawn at stupid predefined places as usual - You are never again vulnerable / without plenty of guns to choose from - it is basically just what FEAR2 was like  Quite disappointing. And alma was in her child form again for some reason, trying to kill you. OK, what? To both points. Why is she a kid again suddenly? Why is she trying to kill you? Why does fettel have you kill your squad rather than just instruct everyone that you're going on a solo mission for a bit? He is a ♥♥♥♥ing commander of the entire replica army after all. Why is alma preventing you, both personally and by way of ordering replicas to kill you, from reviving her dead son? Her son who spent the entirety of the previous game trying to set her free?  This is really just a jumble of plot points shoved together with minimal effort, providing absolutely nothing new. It's just FEAR2 recycled in no particularly interesting way, and a deliberate 'we want more money!' DLC.

Fear 2: Project Origin tells the story of psychic soldiers, crazy little girls, secrets and coverups. There are some cutscenes and readable backstory but seriously, that's not why we are here. We are here for some good old ultra violence. So let's look into that.  The game tries to be cinematic with it's slow-mo combat but now in the year 2015 it fails. The effects that maybe once were cutting edge are now average at best. To get as much sparks in the air as possible there needs to be a lot of bullets flying and what this means is that all weapons are horribly inaccurate and ineffective. Single headshot with assault rifle does nothing, you need 2-3. Spraying at a distance of say 15 meters you can be sure that you need atleast 20-30 smg rounds to kill an enemy. The sniper rifle is the players best friend even indoors.  Project Origin is new enough to have physics modeling but it basically only applies to corpses. Throw a grenade into an office full of desks, books etc. and very little moves. So no redeeming factors there either. Bullet spongy enemies without a proper fireworks display gets old fast. The game has few sections where the player gets to pilot a mech and in those you can destroy a decent amount of the scenery. Why it's restricted only to these levels is beyond me.  What suprised me most though was how powerless the sound design is. The weapon sounds and explosions are really weak. The design is also weird: For example if you stand next to and look at something that makes noise (machine, person talking, burning corpse etc.) you hear the sound it makes. Turn 180 and the sound almost disappears. Face the object again and it returns. When that is added to the lackluster visuals there really isn't much for the senses. Needless to say, on a modern machine Fear 2 runs without problems. On top of that it does have a wide range of graphical options to choose from.  Fear in this game translates into jump scares and they really are not scary. Some of the most gory parts are ghastly but there is no sense of threat. It's just blood and gore. Levels are made of grey facilities or ruins of a city so no wild set design here. At one part of the game the player has to navigate through a literal monster closet factory which was just silly.   Fortunately the AI is really aggressive and they will run after the player like bloodhounds and throw grenades like they have boxes full of them on hand. Only problem is that they tend to come at you one or two at a time so it's rarely overwhelming. On the hardest difficulty the player character dies really easily which is a good thing but it only emphasizes the fact that similarily equiped enemies can take bullets like rain.  In todays market, where there are loads of games available and a lot on sale at all times, you can do much better than Fear 2: Project origin. The first F.E.A.R might have some value as a classic or a game that pushed the genre forward and maybe should be played for that reason. This second installment doesn't even have that quality. It's not unplayable or anything, it just doesn't have much to offer anymore.
If you love fear, then play it. Otherwise no reason to ever pick this up.

What went wrong with F.E.A.R. 2?   The original game was by all accounts a very good game. A great game even; almost certainly one of the best shooters of `05, if not all time. The sequel on the other hand is just wrong. It looks wrong. It feels wrong. It plays wrong.   The first thing you notice when you play the game is the lower FOV, and the intrusive HUD. Combined , these give the sense of claustrophobia within the limited screen space. Imagine walking around looking through the display of a camcorder at arms length from your face and you'll get the picture. The word `consolized`comes up a lot in the old FOV debacle. The theory being the television sits further from the player, and therefore the natural depth in the room counterbalances the lack of depth in the picture, whereas the PC player sits just a couple of feet from the monitor so field of view needs to be wider to compensate. This idea shouldn't be difficult to overlook, and yet it often is.  Secondly, the actual shooting. Yeah. It falls under the initially indefinably wrong category, but after some closer examination it becomes more obvious. Enemies don't really act like F.E.A.R enemies, however I don't think this is a result of the AI. The level design is largely to blame. This game presents the player with very narrow, linear paths that look larger than they actually are. Enemies pop up in an endless battery right in front of you, occupying an oppressively large margin of screen space. There is no room for these poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s to navigate, let alone perform any complicated flanking maneuvers. It is basically a moving feast of whack-a-drone. The player movement is just as restricted; it is weirdly difficult to navigate even the larger areas without getting stuck on miscellaneous props and debris. The game clearly wants you experience every gunfight a certain way, and that alone seals its fate to the bargain bin pile of mediocrity.  This brings me to the guns, the violence, and all of the carnage in between. The guns look wrong. They have that weird plasticy pseudo-futeristic look that clashes with the more conventional settings in the game, not to mention the style of the weapons in the previous game. The same is true for the props, and the character models. The balancing of the weaponry is more akin to a call of duty game thanks to the full implementation of the iron sights mechanism that is so popular these days (not necessarily a bad thing).Unfortunately this came at the cost of all of the familiar idiosyncrasies of the classic shooter that made them so fun (over powered shotgun, deadly accurate pistol, etc.). The F.E.A.R. 2 shotgun is pathetic, the pistol looks weird doesn't feel like the headhunting cannon straight out of a John Woo film that the old .45 did, and finally the dinky sub-machine gun you first get is an unholy bullet saw. What the heck happened there? This of course brings me to the violence. The original game was violent, and it was on occasion gratuitous, but it tended to show its fangs at appropriate times. The predecessor on the other hand goes full on Chuck Manson from the get go. You can literally cut a man in half with a freaking SMG, and its not like some dramatic event, it just happens sometimes. Everything can be going normal in a relatively dull, mundane firefight, and then you look back and notice one baddies is torn up all over the place. It is just bizarre.   This is dragging on, and my list of my eccentric complaints could drag on longer than I actually played the silly game, so I will end it here.

F.E.A.R the disappearing floors ......  Fear 2 is good but not great. The game has a fair few glitches and tiny bugs that end up irratating more then they should across the campaign.   The storys pretty so,so with your character 'Becket' being part of squad sent into some unknown city to extract some scientists that are being hunted by a mercenary group. Recommend playing the first game to better understand whats going on later in the game. So the main plot kicks off after the rescue mission where a physcic zombie chick called Alma hunts you and your team in order to ......mate with you or another team member( this isnt a spoiler its in text log at the very start of the game . All awhile you kill waves of clones and mercs .....Now this plot is fine if a little ridiculous.   Questions like where are miltary? why is there no back up? how are the clones being controlled tactically by some naked lass whos spent her entire life making babies or just sleeping in a tank are never explained.  After a botched rescue mission you end up with a slo mo ability . This is the gameplays core draw as you can dodge bullits, slo mo kick foes and generally act like a bad ♥♥♥. But this is all the same kind of things as the previous game. New weapons are rather uninteresting and dont come quick enough. Quick tip, as soon as you find the assualt rifle keep it the entire game, As with the shotgun in F.E.A.R one its basically the go to weapon that is always useful and never runs out of ammo thanks to numerous drops by the enemy.   Now glitches , i fell through the floor of the game 4 times. Resulting in my death. I was one hit killed at least 20 times by multiple enemies with a submachine gun or similar weapon weak weapon. Numerous times the a.i started shooting me through a wall/my cover. I realise this game is a bit dated now but still its problems that are there ,wont be fixed this many years on.   I played on hard and found it a challenge at points. Mostly down to the problems above however and not due to my own errors in judgment.   Final points this game is fun but has long periods of boredom . The game trys to diversify the gameplay with Mech segments in a miserable grey city and turret segments. However these parts are just boring and dont allow slow mo they are not needed or wanted. The game wouldnt lose anything if it took out both the turret segments or mech scenes.   The story is so average and kind of stupid at points with bland characters......with the exception of one character. The Mercenary boss is awsome. His lines are so bad they are good ...sweet pea.   The series antagonist Alma was creepy in the first game but here, shes just annoying, activating quick time events where you fight her off. She just nocks about wasting time.   Grahipics are good and the game doesnt shy way from gore at all which is refreshing.   Ultimatly i prefered the first game, that would be 8/10 while this. is more of a 6/10 . Despite the diversity of levels the game doesnt feel that different. Which was the main problem with the first game drawing serious repetition by the end. The same enemy types ( despite one or two) and the gameplay is just the same as the previous game. Its just above average. Wait for sale.

Could have just been the illusion of choice in the first game but to me it felt like you could go down more than one route to finish a level. Overall F.E.A.R 2 is a solid, fun shooter with a horror undertone; nice to look at, but perhaps doesn't quite have the same magic as the original F.E.A.R.  It has a relatively quick but enjoyable campaign, containing lots of intense fire fights, vehicle and turret sections without holding your hand too much or dragging you through too many cut scenes.  I gave this a quick run through on 'Normal' and found it mostly quite easy due to the frequent placement of armour and medkits. However the enemy AI provide a decent challenge regardless as you can never stay in one place for too long before you are flanked, outnumbered or grenaded.  As far as the horror aspect goes, it doesn't build tension as well its predecessor, which undermines the 'jump scares' somewhat, but F.E.A.R 2 is a little less predictable in this respect and does provide a lot of disturbing moments none the less.  I'd also recommend playing the first F.E.A.R and its DLC if you want to follow the plotline as having some context makes it a little better I think.  Pros - Shooty bang bang - Good variety of weapon types - Excellent enemy AI on the whole, who seek to use their numbers against you - Slow mo and melee options give you a fun mechanic to use to your advantage - Short and sweet - good for a quick weekend play through - No annoying third party DRM   Cons -Ability to bind to additional mouse buttons would be useful - there are quite a few commands you need at your disposal quickly - Feels Less Horror; more shooty than F.E.A.R

Fear 2, alot of people have mixed emotions about this game. Some say its more of a shooter than a horror game. Others say meh. I think the terror is little bit more scarier in terms of graphics and landscapes. The music is one of the most excellent. Using some of the original and remixed versions of the Fear soundtrack. But also adding some new terrifying music such as the music box. The largest part that glues the game is the story telling more about what happened after the explosion at the end of fear. And also testing the psyche of each of the main characters and scaring the player in the process. Monster are a plus for creativity, such as making mans common friend 'light' even scary! With a variety of monsters to scare you and plenty of enemies to fight its an action packed, psychological-horror sequel worth getting.

Its feels and plays like the first game but everything is much better, even on todays standards the graphics are nice to look. The spacing of the action and walking is just right, you never feel bored or that there are too much action coming without resting. There are some unneeded railshooting scenes but they don't last too long. The level design is much better than before, no more boring or overlong tunnels like in the first game. I think where the first one lasted too long (around 20h) this has just the right length for a FPS game, around 8h to finish.   FEAR series seems to have one of the best positional audios I've ever heard, in the first game there was EAX support but second one has even better audio. I could close my eyes and just from the sounds coming from the enemies I would know where they were and could kill them.  I could say this is the last good FEAR game as third one is more COD clone than it is horror shooter, so if you enjoyed the first game it's very likely you will enjoy this one too if not even more than the first one.

While many would consider the sequel to one of the best horror fps out there a weak one, I will have to disagree.   Though the influence of less innovative shooters are seen in the wrinkles of Project Origin, I would say it still holds up as a fun, action-heavy and quite atmospheric game.   So plug in your headphones,  turn off the music in-game  , then turn out the lights and get ready to be mildly unsettled in a very atmospheric shooter environment.

While not as good as the original, FEAR 2 is still a solid continuation of the FEAR universe’s storyline. The action and bullet time challenges are still very enjoyable, as are the new weapons -- but most notably, the creepy moments still send shivers down your spine even though you already know they're going to happen.
